description: Recorded since c.1300, from Middle English, from Old French deposer, from de- (“down”) + poser (“to put, place”). Deposition (1494 in the legal sense) belongs to deposit, but that related word and depose became thoroughly confused.

verbs.description: depose (third-person singular simple present deposes, present participle deposing, simple past and past participle deposed)

entries.meaning: (literally, transitive) To put down; to lay down; to deposit; to lay aside; to put away.
(transitive) To remove (a leader) from (high) office, without killing the incumbent.
examples: A deposed monarch may go into exile as pretender to the lost throne, hoping to be restored in a subsequent revolution.

entries.meaning: (law, intransitive) To give evidence or testimony, especially in response to interrogation during a deposition
(law, transitive) To interrogate and elicit testimony from during a deposition; typically done by a lawyer.
examples: After we deposed the claimant we had enough evidence to avoid a trial.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To take or swear an oath.
To testify; to bear witness; to claim; to assert; to affirm.
examples: to depose the yearly rent or valuation of lands
